comments.commentBody: I like the idea of paying by the mile and the mileage, but I do not like being tracked where I go.  Too often in the past, government computers and privacy have been compromised; we can safely assume it will happen again.  I also agree with posters who point out that big-rig vehicles are the ones weighing on our infrastructure.  Those of us in the Fayetteville shale territory in Arkansas have watched as drilling rigs and dump trucks do more damage to roads in a year than autos do in ten years.  How about if we reinvigorate our rail system for freight?  As for individuals shifting to public transportation, we need more public transportation too for that idea to work.  Otherwise, the miles tax will be just one more regressive tax with no alternative for those in the middle and working class.

Here in Western Oregon, we have a Lobster Valley and a Lobster Creek.  Of course, there are no lobsters in the creek, since it is fresh water.  But there still is an abundance of crawfish, which are easy to catch though an under-utilized resource.  They are tasty when boiled up, and are an excellent bait for small-mouth bass on the nearby Umpqua River.  Every ten-year-old boy in Lobster Valley knows about them.  I am surprised that  Zabar's in New York has made a popular salad from them.  More power to Mr. Zabar.
Mitchell London would never let this happen. Shame on Mr. Zabar!
A disgrace to crawdads everywhere, calling them lobster.  Despicable.
For 15 years, the label has listed the ingredients as crawfish. How is it possible that nobody noticed this before?

The owners cowardly response is reason enough to question everything about the operation and foods prepared on site. The only honest thing said was that "real" lobster would cost more.

Humans are related to other species but this does not make us the same.

I bet that it is not even crawfish from the bayou but from the rice field in China which is much cheaper. Trying getting a pound of peeled crawfish from New Orleans, it is much more expensive than Main lobster.

Interesting that the Maine Lobster Council will not only take on Zabar's for calling crawfish lobster, but apparently takes the stance that any kind of lobster other than their local variety, such as warm-water spiny lobster, is not "lobster" at all.  Ridiculous.

There is no reason for the excessive lengths of baseball games today. MLB should:

1) Allow the hitter one "time-out" while batting (baring exception circumstances like getting knocked down, fouling a ball off their leg, etc). If the batter steps out again, the pitcher can throw an uncontested pitch.
2) Allow the pitcher 15-20 seconds to throw a pitch with no runner on base. If not thrown then, it is a ball. With a runner on base, 40 seconds. Add an extra umpire to monitor that; along with all the TV instant replays that are inevitably coming.
3) 3-5 warm-up pitches for relief pitchers and at the start of innings. Why do they need 9 pitches? And we know that the fielders don't need more than 1-2 throws to warm up before the inning.
4) Catchers get only 1 trip to the mound per inning, like the coaches and managers. If two, the automatically walk the next batter.
5) Make intentional walks automatical.
6) Cut down all the commercials between innings. I know this is heresy to the owners and might cost a little money, but more people might actually watch the games if they went faster and had more action; thereby raising the ad rates.

I love watching baseball, but the only 3+ hour games ought to be extra innings or a real slugfest.
I noticed the lack of lobster. I always assumed it was because lobster isn't kosher. But now that I think about it, crayfish isn't kosher either. Don't tell my grandma I ate it.

Perhaps they meant to call it "Bayou Lobster"?

Truth is mislabeling in the seafood business is rampant, according to DNA testing.

I have been a customer of Zabar's since the early 70's when Murray Klein was upfront, and Harold in the back, and George, The Sturgeon General was slicing up the 'western' nova.  I am more upset by Zabar's defensive response than the actual 'dishonest' act in the first place. Next thing we'll learn is their delicious chunky chicken salad is actually?????Nonetheless, my favorite lobster salad remains Legal Seafood and Billy's Chowder House in Wells Beach, ME....yes, where they grow the lobster....

Mr. Zabar is being totally disingenuous. Nobody thinks of crawfish as lobster. I live in Maine. My brother went to medical school in New Orleans. Cajuns came from Maine where they were known as Acadians. No one I know has ever heard of crawfish being called lobster.

Zabar's is raking it in better than Bernie Madoff if he's getting $17 a pound for crawfish salad! On principal alone I would stop going to Zabar's. Yes, I used to live in Manhattan so I know what prices are like, but I hope people make a stink about Zabar's highway robbery.

Those of us who have been following the market for decades know that if the market can rocket up 400 points on the kind of data it had today, it can go down 600 on similar news on Monday. These are times for professional traders. The rest of us should put our laptops away and spend the next few weeks worrying about other things.

I'm amazed by the treatment of this as adorable, wacky and cute.

Isn't this fraud?

Aren't there laws against this in New York?

Is there no fear that they might be enforced?
Saul, you're missing an opportunity here. Just call it "Not Lobster Salad."
They cater to the neighborhood. That joint's expensive.

My sense of $9 dollar watches is that they are failed designs.The marginal cost of small electronic devices are astonishingly small. The guy who made the $9 watch was hoping to make a $40 watch but missed the mark.  Most of the ideas you mentioned do not seem worth the intellectual clutter they  bring to the watch. I have not experienced wrist watch alarms that are worth the effort to set, Stop watches I need once every decade or so. I wear a watch that is accurate and easy to read under a huge range of conditions. It requires my input every few years to change the battery.  If  I  want a function beyond time and date I can get it without compromising the use the other 99.999% percent of the time.

c'mon guys, rivalries make for great sports 'theater' - and i'm writing this from johannesburg, south africa. i was born - and remain - a phillies fan and cheered for them when they were terrible as in 1961 and died a thousand deaths when they lost the pennant in 1964 and now i love it when they win. i even get up at 3 am local time to follow the game on internet 'game view'.

let's remember that they were a big market team when they were terrible too. it is the quality of the management/farm system/manager now that gives them the ability to compete. those three things are not givens in the way that a city's population is.

Looks unanimous, and I agree - it's what i've been saying for weeks. Scratch that - months. If it's the money, just eat the crow and don't lose the games. Making up for the stupidity of signing Burnett, is a really lame reason to throw away another season. Bench him. Same excuses every time he pitches. It isn't rocket science, Joe: if they can't win games, they don't belong in the rotation - or for that matter, in the pen.
And after today's three run HR on top of the last two blown saves, Mariano becomes the next official problem for management. Is this just a temporary mechanical problem or the hated inevitable decline? We're in big trouble if the left handed hitters have finally figured out Mo's cutter and the Yankees decide they owe to him to just keep on putting him out there.
Maybe Soriano got back just in time.

Folks, we must remember that neither of the contestants in this 'I bet'cha a million dollars' schoolyard squabble are climate scientists, though both have written extensively on climate issues and Romm is a physicist with a doctorate --> neither is a specialist on Arctic Ice Conditions, though at least Revkin has been there. Romm is mostly a politician (though some use the less desirable but possibly more accurate title, professional hired political hack) and Revkin is mostly a semi-retired Science Journalist, now an opinion columnist. Oddly enough, in a two-sided list of players in the Climate Wars, they are on the same side, though Romm is rather very far to the left, while Revkin is closer to the middle.

The more rabid AGW alarmists always seem to want to make bets, and then attack those who decline the offer, usually implying that 'their' refusal to bet means that 'their' opinion is obviously wrong or that 'they' are somehow morally deficient.

In my opinion, the Romm making an issue of the bet/refusal-to-bet is childish....which I consider much worse than Gore's recent use of use of rough language in a public address.
Here's a link to the Public Workshop of the Committee on the Use of Chimpanzees in Biomedical and Behavioral Research at the Institute of Medicine of the National Academies: http://j.mp/iomChimps

For  those of us who are not paid to manage the Yanks, a quiet resentment toward Girardi is pardonable as WE see things several weeks before HE sees things.  Yes, Nova is to be in the rotation.  DUH!  Now, about this Rivera matter:  Hey, Joe, it's me again:  Soriano is your closer.  Get it?  Mariano is, indeed, the greatest ever, but now is not ever; it is NOW.  AJ does not belong in the pen -- where he is likely to become even more introspective, analytical and nuts.  He belongs in Scranton where, over a course of three or four starts, he just might return to the Bronx in shape to help us into and through the playoffs.  Oh, call it a torn meniscus rather than a brain eruption.  But the kind of help AJ needs begins with his ARM -- as in THROW EACH PITCH AS IF IT IS TO BE YOUR LAST.  Mariano?  I don't know.  You can't get younger on the bench.  There's something his ball is not doing, but his mechanics are as constant as the Northern Star.  We've got an older chap on our hands, and this is the time to give serious thought to when and where he is most likely to reclaim his confidence and his success rate.

JG probably has his mind made up already about AJ and Hughes, but why tip off the writers?  Give them something to write about for another week or two and keep opponents guessing. AJ has SERIOUS problems with his focus, and Hughes has not proved that he has his best stuff back, or ever will. A crap shoot between the two at this point, with emphasis on the crap. JG may get down to flipping a coin and hoping that, whatever his choice, neither pitcher's turn comes up in a critical matchup. AJ has a month to show that he has stuff and the head for competing in NY. Phil is young and has to determine if he has a future as an elite MLB starter. I don't like to bet against my team, but ...

I gave up lobster after learning from David Foster Wallace's "Consider the Lobster" how much lobsters actually suffer from being boiled alive.  They crawl and scratch at the pot, banging on the lid, for the five minutes it takes to cook them down to unconsciousness and beyond.
